author: Joanna Mather
title: Joe Hockey, Josh Frydenberg received no mail on kidnapping rule
text:
The government wants to quarantine private companies from having to reveal their tax affairs. Jim Rice JRZ by Joanna Mather Labor has taken a swipe at the federal government for capitulating to the "big end of town" after a freedom of information request revealed Treasurer Joe Hockey has never received any correspondence about exempting private Australian companies from having to reveal their tax affairs .
Nor has Assistant Treasurer Josh Frydenberg received any emails or letters asking him to consider changing a rule that requires the publication of tax paid by companies with turnover of $100 million or more.
Nevertheless, the government is pushing ahead with legislation to exempt about 1000 private Australian companies from the rule, which was brought in by the previous Labor government.
Kidnapping a concern
Concern that the information might make the wealthy family members who own the companies a target for kidnappers emerged from a Coalition partyroom meeting in March.
Shadow assistant treasurer Andrew Leigh said the government was proposing extra secrecy within the tax laws, "yet they say that not a single stakeholder or community group have written to them about the need for this change".
"Is this serious reform, or the sort of idea that only comes up after the second glass of wine with their mates at the Melbourne Club?"
Mr Leigh's office lodged freedom of information requests with Mr Hockey and Mr Frydenberg on July 2.

View full Quote: Company Profile ASX Announcements Expand ASX Announcements View all announcements The request asked for "copies of all correspondence (in any format) to the [treasurer and assistant treasurer] and his staff regarding altering the scope of rules requiring publication of tax details for companies earning over $100 million".
No documents found
A response dated July 31 says "no documents have been found that would fall within the terms of your request".
The Australian Taxation Office is preparing to later this year publish details of taxable income and tax paid by 2300 companies with annual turnovers of $100 million.
An exemption proposed by the government would spare 1000 privately owned Australian companies on the basis that disclosure would effectively reveal the tax affairs of the individuals and families who own the enterprises. Information about multinationals and public companies would still be published.
This would expose the private companies to a greater level of personal and commercial risk, the draft legislation says.
The government is believed to have the support of at least four of the six cross-bench senators it needs to get legislation passed. Bob Day, David Leyonhjelm, Dio Wang and John Madigan have indicated support.
The family that owns beef exporter Teys Australia has told the government it is worried it will be targeted by criminals on the basis of "perceived wealth" if details of its tax affairs are made public.
Mr Hockey declined to comment.
